1675 Yet more I wish; but how shall I prevail?
1676 Say, gentle Night, whose modest, maiden beams
1677 Give us a new creation, and present
1678 The world's great picture soften'd to the sight;
1679 Nay, kinder far, far more indulgent still,
1680 Say, thou, whose mild dominion's silver key
1681 Unlocks our hemisphere, and sets to view
1682 Worlds beyond number, worlds conceal'd by day
1683 Behind the proud and envious star of noon!
1684 Canst thou not draw a deeper scene? and show
1685 The mighty Potentate, to whom belong
1686 These rich regalia pompously display'd
1687 To kindle that high hope? like him of Uz,
1688 I gaze around; I search on every side: —
1689 O for a glimpse of HIM my soul adores!
1690 As the chased hart, amid the desert waste,
1691 Pants for the living stream; for HIM who made her
1692 So pants the thirsty soul, amid the blank
1693 Of sublunary joys. Say, goddess, where?
1694 Where blazes His bright court? Where burns His throne?
1695 Thou know'st, for thou art near Him; by thee, round
1696 His grand pavilion, sacred Fame reports
1697 The sable curtains drawn. If not, can none
1698 Of thy fair daughter-train, so swift of wing,
1699 Who travel far, discover where He dwells?
1700 A star His dwelling pointed out below.
1701 Ye Pleiades, Arcturus, Mazzaroth,
1702 And thou, Orion, of still keener eye!
1703 Say, ye who guide the wilder'd in the waves,
1704 And bring them out of tempest into port!
1705 On which hand must I bend my course to find Him?
1706 These courtiers keep the secret of their KING;
1707 I wake whole nights, in vain, to steal it from them.
1708 I wake; and, waking, climb Night's radiant scale,
1709 From sphere to sphere; the steps by Nature set
1710 For man's ascent, at once to tempt and aid;
1711 To tempt his eye, and aid his towering thought,
1712 Till it arrives at the Great Goal of all.
1713 In ardent Contemplation's rapid car,
1714 From earth, as from my barrier, I set out.
1715 How swift I mount! Diminish'd earth recedes;
1716 I pass the moon; and from her further side
1717 Pierce heaven's blue curtain; strike into Remote;
1718 Where, with his lifted tube, the subtle sage
1719 His artificial airy journey takes,
1720 And to celestial lengthens human sight.
1721 I pause at every planet on my road,
1722 And ask for HIM who gives their orbs to roll,
1723 Their foreheads fair to shine. From Saturn's ring,
1724 In which of earths an army might be lost,
1725 With the bold comet take my bolder flight
1726 Amid those sovereign glories of the skies,
1727 Of independent, native lustre proud!
1728 The souls of systems, and the lords of life,
1729 Through their wide empires! — What behold I now?
1730 A wilderness of wonders burning round,
1731 Where larger suns inhabit higher spheres?
1732 Perhaps the viUas of descending gods!
1733 Nor halt I here; my toil is but begun,
1734 Tis but the threshold of the DEITY,
1735 Or far beneath it I am grovelling still.
1736 Nor is it strange; I built on a mistake:
1737 The grandeur of His works, whence Folly sought
1738 For aid, to Reason sets His glory higher;
1739 Who built thus high for worms, (mere worms to Him,)
1740 O where, Lorenzo, must the Builder dwell?
1741 Pause, then; and, for a moment, here respire —
1742 If human thought can keep its station here.
1743 Where am I? Where is Earth? Nay, where art thou,
1744 O Sun? — Is the Sun turn'd recluse? — And are
1745 His boasted expeditions short to mine?
1746 To mine, how short! On Nature's Alps I stand,
1747 And see a thousand firmaments beneath,
1748 A thousand systems, as a thousand grains!
1749 So much a stranger, and so late arrived,
1750 How can man's curious spirit not inquire,
1751 What are the natives of this world sublime,
1752 Of this so foreign, unterrestrial sphere,
1753 Where mortal, untranslated, never stray'd?
1754 "O ye, as distant from my little home
1755 As swiftest sunbeams in an age can fly!
1756 Far from my native element I roam,
1757 In quest of New and Wonderful to man.
1758 What province this of His immense domain,
1759 Whom all obeys? Or mortals here, or gods?
1760 Ye borderers on the coasts of bliss, what are you?
1761 A colony from heaven? or only raised,
1762 By frequent visit from heaven's neighbouring realms,
1763 To secondary gods, and half Divine?
1764 Whate'er your nature, this is past dispute, —
1765 Far other life you live, far other tongue
1766 You talk, far other thought, perhaps, you think,
1767 Than man. How various are the works of God!
1768 But say, what thought? Is Reason here enthroned,
1769 And absolute? or Sense in arms against her?
1770 Have you two lights? or need you no reveal'd?
1771 Enjoy your happy realms their golden age?
1772 And had your Eden an abstemious Eve?
1773 Our Eve's fair daughters prove their pedigree.
1774 And ask their Adams, "Who would not be wise? "
1775 Or, if your mother fell, are you redeem'd?
1776 And if redeem'd, is your Redeemer scorn'd?
1777 Is this your final residence? If not,
1778 Change you your scene, translated? or by death?
1779 And if by death, what death? — Know you disease?
1780 Or horrid war? — With war, this fatal hour,
1781 Europa groans (so call we a small field,
1782 Where kings run mad). In our world Death deputes
1783 Intemperance to do the work of Age,
1784 And, hanging up the quiver Nature gave him,
1785 As slow of execution, for despatch
1786 Sends forth imperial butchers; bids them slay
1787 Their sheep, (the silly sheep they fleeced before,)
1788 And toss him twice ten thousand at a meal.
1789 Sit all your executioners on thrones?
1790 With you, can rage for plunder make a GOD,
1791 And bloodshed wash out every other stain? —
1792 But you, perhaps, can't bleed: from matter gross
1793 Your spirits clean are delicately clad
1794 In fine-spun ether, privileged to soar,
1795 Unloaded, uninfected: how unlike
1796 The lot of man! How few of human race
1797 By their own mud unmurder'd! How we wage
1798 Self-war eternal! — Is your painful day
1799 Of hardy conflict o'er? or are you still
1800 Raw candidates at school? And have you those
1801 Who disaffect reversions, as with us? —
1802 But what are we? You never heard of man,
1803 Or earth; the Bedlam of the universe!
1804 Where Reason (undiseased with you) runs mad,
1805 And nurses Folly's children as her own;
1806 Fond of the foulest. In the sacred mount
1807 Of holiness, where Reason is pronounced
1808 Infallible; and thunders, like a god;
1809 E'en there, by saints the demons are outdone:
1810 What these think wrong, our saints refine to right;
1811 And kindly teach dull Hell her own black arts:
1812 Satan, instructed, o'er their morals smiles. —
1813 But this how strange to you, who know not man!
1814 Has the least rumour of our race arrived?
1815 Call'd here Elijah, in his flaming car?
1816 Pass'd by you the good Enoch, on his road
1817 To those fair fields, whence Lucifer was hurl'd;
1818 Who brush'd, perhaps, your sphere, in his descent,
1819 Stain'd your pure crystal ether, or let fall
1820 A short eclipse from his portentous shade?
1821 O that the fiend had lodged on some broad orb
1822 Athwart his way, nor reach'd his present home!
1823 Then blacken'd earth with footsteps foul'd in hell,
1824 Nor wash'd in ocean, as from Rome he pass'd
1825 To Britain's isle; too, too conspicuous there! "
1826 But this is all digression. Where is He
1827 That o'er heaven's battlements the felon hurl'd
1828 To groans, and chains, and darkness? Where is He
1829 Who sees Creation's summit in a vale?
1830 He whom, while man is MAN, he can't but seek;
1831 And, if he finds, commences more than man?
1832 O for a telescope His throne to reach!
1833 Tell me, ye learn'd on earth, or bless'd above!
1834 Ye searching, ye Newtonian angels! tell,
1835 Where your great Master's orb? His planets, where?
1836 Those conscious satellites, those morning stars,
1837 First-born of DEITY! from Central Love,
1838 By veneration most profound, thrown off;
1839 By sweet attraction no less strongly drawn;
1840 Awed, and yet raptured; raptured, yet serene;
1841 Past thought illustrious, but with borrow'd beams;
1842 In still approaching circles, still remote,
1843 Revolving round the sun's eternal Sire?
1844 Or sent, in lines direct, on embassies
1845 To nations — in what latitude? — Beyond
1846 Terrestrial thought's horizon. — And on what
1847 High errands sent? — Here human effort ends;
1848 And leaves me still a stranger to His throne.
1849 Full well it might! I quite mistook my road;
1850 Born in an age more curious than devout;
1851 More fond to fix the place of heaven or hell,
1852 Than studious this to shun, or that secure.
1853 'T is not the curious, but the pious, path
1854 That leads me to my point: Lorenzo, know,
1855 Without or star or angel for their guide,
1856 Who worship GOD shall find Him. Humble Love,
1857 And not proud Reason, keeps the door of heaven;
1858 Love finds admission, where proud Science fails.
1859 Man's science is the culture of his heart;
1860 And not to lose his plummet in the depths
1861 Of Nature, or the more profound of GOD:
1862 Either to know, is an attempt that sets
1863 The wisest on a level with the fool.
1864 To fathom Nature (ill-attempted here!)
1865 Past doubt, is deep philosophy above:
1866 Higher degrees in bliss archangels take,
1867 As deeper learn'd; the deepest, learning still.
1868 For, what a thunder of Omnipotence
1869 (So might I dare to speak) is seen in all!
1870 In man, in earth, in more amazing skies!
1871 Teaching this lesson, Pride is loath to learn: —
1872 "Not deeply to discern, not much to know,
1873 Mankind was born to wonder and adore."
1874 And is there cause for higher wonder still
1875 Than that which struck us from our past surveys?
1876 Yes; and for deeper adoration too.
1877 From my late airy travel unconfined,
1878 Have I learn'd nothing? — Yes, Lorenzo, this: —
1879 Each of these stars is a religious house;
1880 I saw their altars smoke, their incense rise,
1881 And heard Hosannas ring through every sphere,
1882 A seminary fraught with future gods.
1883 Nature all o'er is consecrated ground,
1884 Teeming with growths immortal and Divine.
1885 The great Proprietor's all-bounteous hand
1886 Leaves nothing waste; but sows these fiery fields
1887 With seeds of Reason, which to Virtues rise
1888 Beneath His genial ray; and, if escaped
1889 The pestilential blasts of stubborn Will,
1890 When grown mature, are gather'd for the skies.
1891 And is devotion thought too much on earth,
1892 When beings, so superior, homage boast,
1893 And triumph in prostrations to The Throne?
1894 But wherefore more of planets, or of stars?
1895 Ethereal journeys, and, discover'd there,
1896 Ten thousand worlds, ten thousand ways devout,
1897 All Nature sending incense to The Throne,
1898 Except the bold Lorenzos of our sphere?
1899 Opening the solemn sources of my soul,
1900 Since I have pour'd, like feign'd Eridanus,
1901 My flowing numbers o'er the flaming skies,
1902 Nor see, of fancy or of fact what more
1903 Invites the Muse, — here turn we, and review
1904 Our past nocturnal landscape wide: — then say,
1905 Say then, Lorenzo! with what burst of heart,
1906 The whole, at once, revolving in his thought,
1907 Must man exclaim, adoring, and aghast! —
1908 "O what a Root! O what a branch is here!
1909 O what a Father! what a family!
1910 Worlds, systems, and creations! — and creations,
1911 In one agglomerated cluster, hung,
1912 Great VINE,*
* John xv. 1.
on Thee! On Thee the cluster hangs;
1913 The filial cluster, infinitely spread
1914 In glowing globes, with various being fraught;
1915 And drinks (nectareous draught!) immortal life.
1916 Or, shall I say? (for who can say enough?)
1917 A constellation of ten thousand gems,
1918 (And O! of what dimensions, of what weight!)
1919 Set in one signet, flames on the right hand
1920 Of Majesty Divine! The blazing seal
1921 That deeply stamps on all-created mind,
1922 Indelible, His sovereign attributes,
1923 Omnipotence and Love! that passing bound,
1924 And this surpassing that. Nor stop we here
1925 For want of power in GOD, but thought in Man.
1926 E'en this, acknowledged, leaves us still in debt:
1927 If greater aught, that greater all is Thine,
1928 Dread SIRE! — Accept this miniature of Thee;
1929 And pardon an attempt from mortal thought,
1930 In which archangels might have fail'd unblamed. "
1931 How such ideas of the' ALMIGHTY'S power,
1932 And such ideas of the' ALMIGHTY'S plan,
1933 (Ideas not absurd,) distend the thought
1934 Of feeble mortals! nor of them alone!
1935 The fulness of the DEITY breaks forth
1936 In Inconceivables to men and gods.
1937 Think, then, O think, nor ever drop the thought,
1938 How low must man descend, when gods adore!
1939 Have I not, then, accomplish'd my proud boast?
1940 Did I not tell thee, we would mount, Lorenzo,
1941 And "kindle our devotion at the stars?"
1942 And have I fail'd? And did I flatter thee?
1943 And art all adamant? And dost confute
1944 All urged, with one irrefragable smile?
1945 Lorenzo! mirth how miserable here!
1946 Swear by the stars, by HIM who made them, swear,
1947 Thy heart, henceforth, shall be as pure as they!
1948 Then thou, like them, shalt shine; like them, shalt rise
1949 From low to lofty, from obscure to bright,
1950 By due gradation, Nature's sacred law.
1951 The stars, from whence? — Ask Chaos: he can tell.
1952 These bright temptations to idolatry
1953 From darkness and confusion took their birth;
1954 Sons of deformity! From fluid dregs
1955 Tartarean, first they rose to masses rude,
1956 And then to spheres opaque; then dimly shone;
1957 Then brighten'd; then blazed out in perfect day.
1958 Nature delights in progress; in advance
1959 From worse to better: but, when minds ascend,
1960 Progress in part depends upon themselves.
1961 Heaven aids exertion; greater makes the great;
1962 The voluntary little lessens more.
1963 O be a man, and thou shalt be a god,
1964 And half self-made! — Ambition how Divine!
1965 O thou, ambitious of disgrace alone,
1966 Still undevout, unkindled? though high-taught,
1967 School'd by the skies, and pupil of the stars!
1968 Rank coward to the fashionable world,
1969 Art thou ashamed to bend thy knee to Heaven?
1970 Cursed fume of pride, exhaled from deepest hell!
1971 Pride in religion is man's highest praise.
1972 Bent on destruction, and in love with death!
1973 Not all these luminaries, quench'd at once,
1974 Were half so sad as one benighted mind,
1975 Which gropes for happiness, and meets despair.
1976 How, like a widow in her weeds, the Night,
1977 Amid her glimmering tapers, silent sits!
1978 How sorrowful, how desolate, she weeps
1979 Perpetual dews, and saddens Nature's scene!
1980 A scene more sad Sin makes the darken'd soul,
1981 All comfort kills, nor leaves one spark alive.
1982 Though blind of heart, still open is thine eye:
1983 Why such magnificence in all thou seest?
1984 Of matter's grandeur, know, one end is this,
1985 To tell the rational who gazes on it, —
1986 "Though that immensely great, still greater He
1987 Whose breast capacious can embrace and lodge,
1988 Unburden'd, Nature's universal scheme;
1989 Can grasp Creation with a single thought;
1990 Creation grasp; and not exclude its SIRE:"
1991 To tell him farther, — "It behoves him much
1992 To guard the' important, yet depending, fate
1993 Of being brighter than a thousand suns:
1994 One single ray of thought outshines them all."
1995 And if man hears obedient, soon he'll soar
1996 Superior heights, and on his purple wing,
1997 His purple wing bedropp'd with eyes of gold,
1998 Rising, where thought is now denied to rise,
1999 Look down triumphant on these dazzling spheres.
2000 Why then persist? — No mortal ever lived,
2001 But, dying, he pronounced (when words are true)
2002 The whole that charms thee absolutely vain;
2003 Vain, and far worse! — Think thou with dying men;
2004 O condescend to think as angels think!
2005 O tolerate a chance for happiness!
2006 Our nature such, ill choice insures ill fate;
2007 And hell had been, though there had been no God.
2008 Dost thou not know, my new astronomer,
2009 Earth, turning from the sun, brings night to man?
2010 Man, turning from his God, brings endless night;
2011 Where thou canst read no morals, find no friend,
2012 Amend no manners, and expect no peace.
2013 How deep the darkness! and the groan, how loud!
2014 And far, how far, from lambent are the flames!
2015 Such is Lorenzo's purchase, such his praise!
2016 The proud, the politic Lorenzo's praise!
2017 Though in his ear, and levell'd at his heart,
2018 I've half read o'er the volume of the skies.
2019 For think not thou hast heard all this from me;
2020 My song but echoes what great Nature speaks.
2021 What has she spoken? Thus the goddess spoke,
2022 Thus speaks for ever: — "Place at Nature's head
2023 A Sovereign, which o'er all things rolls His eye,
2024 Extends His wing, promulgates His commands,
2025 But, above all, diffuses endless good;
2026 To whom, for sure redress, the wrong'd may fly,
2027 The vile for mercy, and the pain'd for peace;
2028 By whom the various tenants of these spheres,
2029 Diversified in fortunes, place, and powers,
2030 Raised in enjoyment, as in worth they rise,
2031 Arrive at length (if worthy such approach)
2032 At that bless'd fountain-head from which they stream;
2033 Where conflict past redoubles present joy;
2034 And present joy looks forward on increase;
2035 And that on more; no period! every step
2036 A double boon, a promise and a bliss."
2037 How easy sits this scheme on human hearts!
2038 It suits their make, it soothes their vast desires;
2039 Passion is pleased, and Reason asks no more:
2040 'T is rational, 't is great! — But what is thine?
2041 It darkens, shocks, excruciates, and confounds!
2042 Leaves us quite naked both of help and hope,
2043 Sinking from bad to worse; few years, the sport
2044 Of Fortune; then, the morsel of Despair.
2045 Say then, Lorenzo, (for thou know'st it well,)
2046 What's vice? — Mere want of compass in our thought.
2047 Religion, what? — The proof of common-sense.
2048 How art thou hooted, where the least prevails!
2049 Is it my fault if these truths call thee "fool?"
2050 And thou shalt never be miscall'd by me.
2051 Can neither shame nor terror stand thy friend?
2052 And art thou still an insect in the mire?
2053 How, like thy guardian angel, have I flown;
2054 Snatch'd thee from earth; escorted thee through all
2055 The' ethereal armies; walk'd thee, like a god,
2056 Through splendours of flast magnitude, arranged
2057 On either hand; clouds thrown beneath thy feet;
2058 Close cruised on the bright paradise of God;
2059 And almost introduced thee to The Throne!
2060 And art thou still carousing, for delight,
2061 Rank poison; flast fermenting to mere froth,
2062 And then subsiding into final gall?
2063 To beings of sublime, immortal make,
2064 How shocking is all joy whose end is sure!
2065 Such joy more shocking still, the more it charms!
2066 And dost thou choose what ends ere well begun,
2067 And infamous as short? And dost thou choose
2068 (Thou, to whose palate glory is so sweet)
2069 To wade into perdition, through contempt,
2070 Not of poor bigots only, but thy own?
2071 For I have peep'd into thy cover'd heart,
2072 And seen it blush beneath a boastful brow;
2073 For, by strong Guilt's most violent assault,
2074 Conscience is but disabled, not destroy'd.
2075 O thou most awful being, and most vain!
2076 Thy will, how frail! how glorious is thy power!
2077 Though dread Eternity has sown her seeds
2078 Of bliss and woe in thy despotic breast;
2079 Though heaven and hell depend upon thy choice,
2080 A butterfly comes 'cross, and both are fled.
2081 Is this the picture of a rational?
2082 This horrid image, shall it be most just?
2083 Lorenzo! no: it cannot, shall not, be,
2084 If there is force in reason; or in sounds
2085 Chanted beneath the glimpses of the moon,
2086 A magic, at this planetary hour,
2087 When slumber locks the general lip, and dreams
2088 Through senseless mazes hunt souls uninspired.
2089 Attend — the sacred mysteries begin —
2090 My solemn night-born adjuration hear.
2091 Hear, and I'll raise thy spirit from the dust,
2092 While the stars gaze on this enchantment new;
2093 Enchantment, not infernal, but Divine!
2094 "By Silence, Death's peculiar attribute;
2095 By Darkness, Guilt's inevitable doom;
2096 By Darkness and by Silence, sisters dread!
2097 That draw the curtain round Night's ebon throne,
2098 And raise ideas solemn as the scene!
2099 By NIGHT, and all of Awful, Night presents
2100 To Thought or Sense! (of Awful much to both
2101 The goddess brings!) By these her trembling fires,
2102 Like Vesta's, ever burning; and, like hers,
2103 Sacred to thoughts immaculate and pure!
2104 By these bright orators, that prove, and praise,
2105 And press thee to revere, the DEITY;
2106 Perhaps, too, aid thee, when revered awhile,
2107 To reach His throne; as stages of the soul,
2108 Through which, at different periods, she shall pass,
2109 Refining gradual, for her final height,
2110 And purging off some dross at every sphere!
2111 By this dark pall thrown o'er the silent world!
2112 By the world's kings, and kingdoms, most renown'd,
2113 From short ambition's zenith set for ever;
2114 Sad presage to vain boasters now in bloom!
2115 By the long list of swift mortality,
2116 From Adam downward to this evening knell,
2117 Which Midnight waves in Fancy's startled eye;
2118 And shocks her with a hundred centuries,
2119 Round Death's black banner throng'd, in human thought!
2120 By thousands, now resigning their last breath,
2121 And calling thee — wert thou so wise to hear!
2122 By tombs o'er tombs arising; human earth
2123 Ejected, to make room for — human earth;
2124 The monarch's terror, and the sexton's trade!
2125 By pompous obsequies, that shun the day,
2126 The torch funereal, and the nodding plume,
2127 Which makes poor man's humiliation proud;
2128 Boast of our ruin, triumph of our dust!
2129 By the damp vault that weeps o'er royal bones;
2130 And the pale lamp that shows the ghastly dead,
2131 More ghastly, through the thick incumbent gloom!
2132 By visits (if there are) from darker scenes,
2133 The gliding spectre, and the groaning grove!
2134 By groans and graves, and miseries that groan
2135 For the grave's shelter! By desponding men,
2136 Senseless to pains of death, from pangs of guilt!
2137 By Guilt's last audit! By yon moon in blood,
2138 The rocking firmament, the falling stars,
2139 And thunder's last discharge, great Nature's knell!
2140 By second Chaos, and eternal Night!"—
2141 Be wise: — Nor let Philander blame my charm;
2142 But own not ill-discharged my double debt, —
2143 Love to the living, duty to the dead.
2144 For know, I'm but executor: he left
2145 This moral legacy! I make it o'er
2146 By his command: Philander hear in me;
2147 And Heaven in both. — If deaf to these, O hear
2148 Florello's tender voice; his weal depends
2149 On thy resolve; it trembles at thy choice:
2150 For his sake — love thyself. Example strikes
2151 All human hearts; a bad example more;
2152 More still a father's; that insures his ruin.
2153 As parent of his being, wouldst thou prove
2154 The' unnatural parent of his miseries,
2155 And make him curse the being which thou gavest?
2156 Is this the blessing of so fond a father?
2157 If careless of Lorenzo, spare, O spare
2158 Florello's father, and Philander's friend!
2159 Florello's father, ruin'd, ruins him;
2160 And from Philander's friend the world expects
2161 A conduct, no dishonour to the dead.
2162 Let passion do what nobler motive should;
2163 Let love, and emulation, rise in aid
2164 To reason; and persuade thee to be — bless'd.
2165 This seems not a request to be denied;
2166 Yet (such the' infatuation of mankind!)
2167 'T is the most hopeless man can make to man.
2168 Shall I, then, rise in argument and warmth,
2169 And urge Philander's posthumous advice,
2170 From topics yet unbroach'd? —
2171 But, O, I faint! my spirits fail! Nor strange!
2172 So long on wing, and in no middle clime;
2173 To which my great Creator's glory call'd,
2174 And calls — but now in vain. Sleep's dewy wand
2175 Has stroked my drooping lids, and promises
2176 My long arrear of rest; the downy god
2177 (Wont to return with our returning peace)
2178 Will pay, ere long, and bless me with repose.
2179 Haste, haste, sweet stranger, from the peasant's cot,
2180 The ship-boy's hammock, or the soldier's straw,
2181 Whence sorrow never chased thee! With thee bring,
2182 Not hideous visions, as of late; but draughts
2183 Delicious of well-tasted, cordial rest;
2184 Man's rich restorative; his balmy bath,
2185 That supples, lubricates, and keeps in play
2186 The various movements of this nice machine,
2187 Which asks such frequent periods of repair.
2188 When tired with vain rotations of the day,
2189 Sleep winds us up for the succeeding dawn;
2190 Fresh we spin on, till sickness clogs our wheels,
2191 Or Death quite breaks the spring, and motion ends.
2192 When will it end with me?
2192 — — "Thou only know'st,
2193 Thou, whose broad eye the future and the past
2194 Joins to the present; making one of three
2195 To mortal thought! Thou know'st, and Thou alone,
2196 All-knowing! all-unknown! and yet well-known!
2197 Near, though remote; and, though unfathom'd, felt!
2198 And, though invisible, for ever seen!
2199 And seen in all, the great and the minute!
2200 Each globe above, with its gigantic race,
2201 Each flower, each leaf, with its small people swarm'd,
2202 (Those puny vouchers of Omnipotence!)
2203 To the first thought that asks, "From whence?" declare
2204 Their common source. Thou Fountain, running o'er
2205 In rivers of communicated joy!
2206 Who gavest us speech for far, far humbler themes!
2207 Say, by what name shall I presume to call
2208 Him I see burning in these countless suns,
2209 As Moses, in the bush? Illustrious Mind!
2210 The whole creation less, far less, to Thee,
2211 Than that to the creation's ample round.
2212 How shall I name Thee? — How my labouring soul
2213 Heaves underneath the thought, too big for birth!
2214 "Great System of perfections! Mighty Cause
2215 Of causes mighty! Cause uncaused! Sole Root
2216 Of Nature, that luxuriant growth of GOD!
2217 First Father of effects, that progeny
2218 Of endless series! where the golden chain's
2219 Last link admits a period, who can tell?
2220 Father of all that is or heard or hears!
2221 Father of all that is or seen or sees!
2222 Father of all that is or shall arise!
2223 Father of this immeasurable mass
2224 Of matter multiform, or dense or rare,
2225 Opaque or lucid, rapid or at rest,
2226 Minute, or passing bound! in each extreme,
2227 Of like amaze and mystery to man.
2228 Father of these bright millions of the night!
2229 Of which the least full Godhead had proclaim'd,
2230 And thrown the gazer on his knee. — Or, say,
2231 Is appellation higher still Thy choice?
2232 Father of matter's temporary lords!
2233 Father of spirits, nobler offspring! sparks
2234 Of high paternal glory; rich-endow'd
2235 With various measures, and with various modes
2236 Of instinct, reason, intuition; beams
2237 More pale or bright, from day Divine, to break
2238 The Dark of matter organized; (the ware
2239 Of all created spirit;) beams, that rise
2240 Each over other in superior light,
2241 Till the last ripens into lustre strong,
2242 Of next approach to Godhead. Father fond
2243 (Far fonder than e'er bore that name on earth)
2244 Of intellectual beings! beings bless'd
2245 With powers to please Thee; not of passive ply
2246 To laws they know not! beings lodged in seats
2247 Of well-adapted joys, in different domes
2248 Of this imperial palace for Thy sons;
2249 Of this proud, populous, well-policied,
2250 Though boundless, habitation, plann'd by Thee;
2251 Whose several clans their several climates suit;
2252 And transposition, doubtless, would destroy.
2253 Or, O! indulge, Immortal King! indulge
2254 A title, less august indeed, but more
2255 Endearing; ah! how sweet in human ears,
2256 Sweet in our ears, and triumph in our hearts!
2257 Father of Immortality to man!
2258 A theme that lately set my soul on fire. —
2259 And Thou the next, yet equal! Thou, by whom
2260 That blessing was convey'd, (far more!) was bought,
2261 Ineffable the price! by whom all worlds
2262 Were made, and one redeem'd! illustrious Light,
2263 From light illustrious! Thou, whose regal power,
2264 Finite in time, but infinite in space,
2265 On more than adamantine basis fix'd,
2266 O'er more, far more, than diadems and thrones
2267 Inviolably reigns; the dread of gods!
2268 And, O! the friend of man! beneath whose foot,
2269 And by the mandate of whose awful nod,
2270 All regions, revolutions, fortunes, fates,
2271 Of high, of low, of mind and matter, roll
2272 Through the short channels of expiring Time,
2273 Or shoreless ocean of eternity,
2274 Calm or tempestuous, (as thy Spirit breathes,)
2275 In absolute subjection! — And, O Thou,
2276 The glorious Third! distinct, not separate!
2277 Beaming from both, with both incorporate!
2278 And (strange to tell!) incorporate with dust!
2279 By condescension, as Thy glory, great,
2280 Enshrined in man! of human hearts, if pure,
2281 Divine inhabitant! the tie Divine
2282 Of Heaven with distant earth! by whom, I trust,
2283 (If not inspired) uncensured this address
2284 To Thee, to them — To whom? Mysterious power!
2285 Reveal'd, yet unreveal'd! Darkness in light!
2286 Number in unity! our joy, our dread!
2287 The triple bolt that lays all wrong in ruin!
2288 That animates all right, the triple Sun!
2289 Sun of the Soul, her never-setting Sun!
2290 Triune, unutterable, unconceived,
2291 Absconding yet demonstrable, Great God!
2292 Greater than greatest, better than the best!
2293 Kinder than kindest! with soft Pity's eye,
2294 Or (stronger still to speak it) with Thine own,
2295 From Thy bright home, from that high firmament,
2296 Where Thou, from all eternity, hast dwelt,
2297 Beyond archangel's unassisted ken;
2298 From far above what mortals highest call;
2299 From elevation's pinnacle; look down,
2300 Through — what? Confounding interval! through all,
2301 And more than labouring Fancy can conceive, —
2302 Through radiant ranks of essences unknown;
2303 Through hierarchies from hierarchies detach'd,
2304 Round various banners of Omnipotence,
2305 With endless change of rapturous duties fired;
2306 Through wondrous beings' interposing swarms,
2307 All clustering at the call, to dwell in Thee;
2308 Through this wide waste of worlds; this vista vast,
2309 All sanded o'er with suns! suns turn'd to night
2310 Before Thy feeblest beam, — Look down, down, down,
2311 On a poor breathing particle in dust,
2312 Or, lower, — an immortal in his crimes.
2313 His crimes forgive; forgive his virtues too, —
2314 Those smaller faults, half-converts to the right!
2315 Nor let me close these eyes, which never more
2316 May see the sun, (though night's descending scale
2317 Now weighs up morn,) unpitied and unbless'd!
2318 In Thy displeasure dwells eternal pain:
2319 Pain, our aversion; pain, which strikes me now:
2320 And, since all pain is terrible to man,
2321 Though transient, terrible; at Thy good hour,
2322 Gently, ah! gently, lay me in my bed,
2323 My clay-cold bed! by Nature, now, so near!
2324 By Nature, near; still nearer by Disease!
2325 Till then, be this an emblem of my grave!
2326 Let it out-preach the Preacher; every night
2327 Let it out-cry the boy at Philip's ear;
2328 That tongue of death, that herald of the tomb!
2329 And when (the shelter of Thy wing implored)
2330 My senses, soothed, shall sink in soft repose;
2331 O sink this truth still deeper in my soul,
2332 Suggested by my pillow, sign'd by Fate,
2333 First, in Fate's volume, at the page of Man: —
2334 Man's sickly soul, though turn'd and toss'd for ever
2335 From side to side, can rest on nought but Thee, —
2336 Here in full trust, hereafter in full joy;
2337 On Thee, the promised, sure, eternal down
2338 Of spirits, toil'd in travel through this vale.
2339 Nor of that pillow shall my soul despond;
2340 For — Love almighty! Love almighty! (Sing,
2341 Exult, Creation!) Love almighty reigns!
2342 That death of death, that cordial of despair!
2343 And loud Eternity's triumphant song!
2344 "Of whom no more: for, O thou Patron-God!
2345 Thou God and mortal! thence more God to man!
2346 Man's theme eternal, man's eternal theme!
2347 Thou canst not 'scape uninjured from our praise.
2348 Uninjured from our praise can He escape,
2349 Who, disembosom'd from the Father, bows
2350 The heaven of heavens, to kiss the distant earth?
2351 Breathes out in agonies a sinless soul;
2352 Against the cross, Death's iron sceptre breaks;
2353 From famish'd Ruin plucks her human prey;
2354 Throws wide the gates celestial to his foes;
2355 Their gratitude, for such a boundless debt,
2356 Deputes their suffering brothers to receive;
2357 And, if deep human guilt in payment fails,
2358 As deeper guilt, prohibits our despair,
2359 Enjoins it, as our duty, to rejoice;
2360 And, (to close all,) omnipotently kind,
2361 Takes His delights among the sons of men?"*
* Prov. viii.
2362 What words are these? — And did they come from heaven?
2363 And were they spoke to man? to guilty man?
2364 What are all mysteries to love like this?
2365 The songs of angels, all the melodies
2366 Of choral gods, are wafted in the sound;
2367 Heal and exhilarate the broken heart,
2368 Though plunged before in horrors dark as night:
2369 Rich prelibation of consummate joy!
2370 Nor wait we dissolution to be bless'd.
2371 This final effort of the moral Muse,
2372 How justly titled! *
* The Consolation.
Nor for me alone;
2373 For all that read! What spirit of support,
2374 What heights of Consolation, crown my song!
2375 Then farewell, NIGHT! Of darkness now no more:
2376 Joy breaks, shines, triumphs; 't is eternal day.
2377 Shall that which rises out of nought complain
2378 Of a few evils, paid with endless joys?
2379 My soul! henceforth, in sweetest union join
2380 The two supports of human happiness,
2381 Which some erroneous think can never meet, —
2382 True taste of life, and constant thought of death;
2383 The thought of death, sole victor of its dread!
2384 Hope be thy joy, and probity thy skill;
2385 Thy Patron, He whose diadem has dropp'd
2386 Yon gems of heaven; eternity, thy prize:
2387 And leave the racers of the world their own,
2388 Their feather, and their froth, for endless toils:
2389 They part with all for that which is not bread;
2390 They mortify, they starve, on wealth, fame, power;
2391 And laugh to scorn the fools that aim at more.
2392 How must a spirit, late escaped from earth, —
2393 Suppose Philander's, Lucia's, or Narcissa's, —
2394 The truth of things new-blazing in its eye,
2395 Look back, astonish'd, on the ways of men,
2396 Whose lives' whole drift is to forget their graves!
2397 And when our present privilege is pass'd,
2398 To scourge us with due sense of its abuse,
2399 The same astonishment will seize us all.
2400 What then must pain us, would preserve us now.
2401 Lorenzo! 't is not yet too late; Lorenzo!
2402 Seize Wisdom, ere 't is torment to be wise;
2403 That is, seize Wisdom, ere she seizes thee.
2404 For what, my small philosopher, is Hell?
2405 'T is nothing but full knowledge of the Truth,
2406 When Truth, resisted long, is sworn our foe,
2407 And calls Eternity to do her right.
2408 Thus, Darkness aiding intellectual light,
2409 And sacred Silence whispering truths Divine,
2410 And truths Divine converting pain to peace,
2411 My song the midnight raven has outwing'd,
2412 And shot, ambitious of unbounded scenes,
2413 Beyond the flaming limits of the world,
2414 Her gloomy flight. But what avails the flight
2415 Of Fancy, when our hearts remain below?
2416 Virtue abounds in flatterers and foes;
2417 'T is pride to praise her, penance to perform.
2418 To more than words, to more than worth of tongue,
2419 Lorenzo! rise at this auspicious hour:
2420 An hour when Heaven's most intimate with man;
2421 When, like a falling star, the ray Divine
2422 Glides swift into the bosom of the just;
2423 And just are all, determined to reclaim;
2424 Which sets that title high, within thy reach.
2425 Awake then; thy Philander calls; awake!
2426 Thou who shalt wake when the creation sleeps;
2427 When, like a taper, all these suns expire;
2428 When Time, like him of Gaza, in his wrath,
2429 Plucking the pillars that support the world,
2430 In Nature's ample ruins lies entomb'd;
2431 And Midnight, universal Midnight, reigns.
End of the Night Thoughts.

About this text

Title (in Source Edition): [The Complaint: or, Night-Thoughts on Life, Death & Immortality.] Night IX. The Consolation.
Author: Edward Young
Themes: reason; God; religion; death
Genres: blank verse; meditation; graveyard school

Text view / Document view

Source edition

Young, Edward, 1683-1765. Night Thoughts on Life, Death, and Immortality; and a paraphrase on part of the Book of Job. By the Rev. Edward Young, LL.D., sometime rector of Welwyn, Herts. Revised and collated with the early Quarto editions. With a life of the author by Dr. [John] Doran [poem only]. Illustrated. Third edition. London: William Tegg and Co., 85, Queen-Street, Cheapside, 1859. 

Editorial principles

Typography, spelling, capitalization, and punctuation have been cautiously modernized. The source of the text is given and all significant editorial interventions have been recorded in textual notes. This text has been edited to conform to the recommendations found in Level 5 of the Best Practices for TEI in Libraries version 4.0.0.
